title: Mr. Hogarth's Will
author: Spence, Catherine Helen
snippet: To-morrow for inquiries. First a fileof the TIMES for 18-; the police reports, the coroner's inquests, thepassenger-list of the Sydney ship and of the American ship, inquiriesat the lodging-house near the wharf--then to Edinburgh to inquire atthe house in New Street, and consult with MacFarlane and Sinclair. Isurely can work through it--at least I will try."

title: Mr. Hogarth's Will
author: Spence, Catherine Helen
snippet: Next he went to Edinburgh and inquired in New Street, in the old town,for the woman, Violet Strachan, who had let the lodgings where the realFrancis Hogarth was born, and where the irregular marriage had alsotaken place. Thirty-five years in a city like Edinburgh, with aneminently migrating population, is a far more unmanageable period thanin a country town, where people inhabit the same houses from onegeneration to another, and where, even if the persons whom you wish todiscover are dead, there are neighbours who recollect about them.

title: Mr. Hogarth's Will
author: Spence, Catherine Helen
snippet: "Oh, older by ten years," said Mrs. Peck, feeling the ground give wayunder her. "I hope she is not dead--she lived in 57, New Street,leading down to the Canongate, up three pair of stairs; her husband wasa saddler, and she kept lodgers. His name was George.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Is now ready, and may be had in the Town Hall, and the Midland Educational Co.'s Warehouse, New Street.

title: Old world scenes /
author: Williams, Charles
snippet: It is a populous, noisy and bustling  city, but save for its manufactories,, has no great attraction  for the transient visitor. New Street is a splendid thoroughfare, lined with buildings of the most superfluous decoration, and thronged by hurrying thousands. What a pity it has so ridiculous a name.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: New Street was built shortly before the rise of the New Town, and had the honour of containing the residences of Lord Kames, Lord Hailes, and Sir Philip Ainslie. A radiation of the stones in the causeway marks the site of St. John's Cross, where Charles I. knighted the Provost of Edinburgh in 1633.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: St. John Street, like New Street, was one of the first row of modern houses that prognosticated the rise of the new town.

title: The Old Man in the Corner
author: Orczy, Emmuska Orczy, Baroness
snippet: "On the 13th the Hon. Robert Ingram de Genneville arrived at the CastleHotel in New Street for his wedding, and on the 14th, at eight o'clockin the morning, he was discovered lying on the floor of hisbedroom--murdered.
